ygData.subject: Re: rtNEAT License?
ygData.msgSnippet: Chris, There are several important points on this: 1) If you are only using NEAT (that is, you are not using the real- time rt portion of the code), then

Chris,

There are several important points on this:

1) If you are only usi=
ng NEAT (that is, you are not using the real-
time "rt" portion of the code=
), then don't worry about the rtNEAT 
license.  It is only meant for people=
 using real-time NEAT.   I 
suggest you cut out the "rt" code before distri=
buting and then use the 
regular GPL license that comes with NEAT.

2) If y=
ou do want to use rtNEAT, I do not control the license.  The 
University of=
 Texas at Austin owns the license and the technology 
(i.e. the real-time d=
erivative of NEAT) is patent pending.  Thus, the 
license is unlikely to ch=
ange.  However...

3) The current rtNEAT license allows you to distribute y=
our work and 
have others build on it for research purposes.  The only rest=
riction 
is on commercialization, in which case you'd need to contact UT 
A=
ustin.  Thus, for most purpoes, the current rtNEAT license is not 
restrict=
ive.

I am guessing in your particular case you are just using regular NEAT=
 
and therefore the rtNEAT license is a moot point.  You only downloaded 
t=
he "rtNEAT" code to because it contains within it a more easy-to-
compile v=
ersion of regular NEAT.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Spencer" =
<chrisspen@...> wrote:
>
> Ken,
> 
> Would it be possible to release rtNEAT=
 under the GPL, LGPL, or 
similar
> open source license? I'd like to eventu=
ally release my work under one
> of these open source licenses, but I don't=
 think the current UT
> Research License would permit that.
> 
> Regards,
>=
 Chris
>
